section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials drawing and writing supplies, Alphabet Cards, Summer!, Toucan Can Talk

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we read Penguin Day. We saw the letter s in the word sleepy and the letter t in the word tired.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Teach Ss Alphabet Cards Show the Alphabet Cards for the letters Ss. Say the letter aloud and invite children to repeat. This is uppercase S. The letter Ssun makes the /s/ sound you hear in the word ss. This is lowercase. The letter makes the /s/ sound you hear in sock.

Teach Tt Alphabet Cards Show the Alphabet Cards for the letters Tt. Say the letter aloud and invite children to repeat. This is uppercase T. The letter T makes the /t/ sound you hear in the word tiger. This is lowercase t. The letter t makes the /t/ sound you hear in turtle.
Explain the Activity Show Summer! and Toucan Can Talk. Today we will read a book about the letters Ss and the letters Tt.
Read Read aloud Summer! with the provided prompt.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Touch your nose when you hear a word that begins with /s/.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Read Read aloud Toucan Can Talk with the provided prompt.
Ask Pat your head when you hear a word that begins with /t/.

Practice Forming the Letters Ss and Tt Help children practice forming the letters Ss and the letters Tt. Model writing the letters Ss and the letters Tt. Provide drawing supplies. Challenge children to practice writing the letters Ss and the letters Tt.

As you read Summer!, stop at each word that begins with the letter Ss. Invite children to say /s/ and the word that begins with Ss. Repeat with Toucan Can Talk and the letter Tt. For children who need assistance, before writing invite them to trace letters in trays of sand.

After reading each story, challenge children to try to remember all the words that begin with the target sound and letter. Then ask children to name any other words they know that begin with that letter and sound.
Be aware that the Spanish phoneme /t/ is softer than the English phoneme /t/. Take time, as needed, to review the English phoneme /s/ and /t/ and invite children to say the sounds with you.

As you read the books, encourage children to indicate when they see the letters Ss or the letters Tt on the page. Read aloud the word in which the letter is found and have children repeat after you. Providing children an active role as you read aloud helps keep children engaged in the activity.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials manipulatives of three different colors

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we read Penguin Day. We read about the problems the penguins had and how they solved them. Who can remember baby penguin’s problem? What did mama penguin do to solve baby penguin’s problem? Mama penguin went on a journey to bring back food for baby penguin.
Just like mama penguin solved baby penguin’s problem by bringing back food, when we have a problem, we look for a way to solve the problem.
Today we have a sorting problem to solve. The colors are all mixed-up! We need to sort them into different groups. Let’s see if we can solve our problem!

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Set Up Place the manipulatives in front of you. Separate them into groups of two by color.
Ask Hold up a manipulative of the first color. Ask children which pile the manipulative belongs to. Place the manipulative in the first color pile.

Repeat Hold up a second manipulative of the second color. Ask children where the manipulative should go. Place the manipulative in the second color pile. Continue this process, inviting children to take turns sorting the manipulatives, until all of the manipulatives are sorted. Encourage children to help each other as they sort the manipulatives.
Talk About Problem Solving Techniques Once the manipulatives have all been sorted, invite children to reflect on the activity. What was the problem we had? How did we solve our problem?
Scaffold the activity such as using fewer manipulatives to sort or only providing two or three different colors. Walk children through the activity by saying the colors aloud each round.

Add another set of manipulatives. Challenge children to identify other ways the manipulatives can be sorted such as size or shape. Invite children to take turns placing the manipulatives in piles and let partners work together, fostering communication skills.
Help multilingual learners identify the English names for colors. Take time, as needed, to review colors such as red, orange, yellow, green, blue, and purple.

Encourage children to build their fine motor skills by picking up individual manipulatives with their thumb and forefinger. See if they can gently place the manipulative in the correct pile. Provide support as needed.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials Activity Cards

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we read . We read about how mama penguin and papa penguin care for baby penguin. We saw pictures of baby penguin and mama and papa penguin.
Baby penguin has feathers just like mama and papa penguin. Baby penguin also has a beak and wings just like mama and papa penguin.
Other baby animals are like their mama and papa too. We’re going to match up each adult animal with its baby.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Set Up Place the six cards face up.

Ask Share one adult animal picture card and read the questions on the back of the card. Ask children to find the matching baby card. Read the questions on the back of the card. Have children share what’s alike between the adult animal and baby animal.

Repeat Continue the activity until each adult animal card is matched up with its baby card. Provide extra support and prompting as necessary and discuss the similarities shared between each animal and baby pair.

Talk About Adult Animals and Baby Animals Invite children to talk about how they matched up each animal pair. Encourage children to think about what’s alike between each animal and baby pair. Then ask children to think about the differences between adult animals and their babies. Provide extra support and prompting as needed.
Point to each card and name the animal. Let children listen to you name each animal. Then see if children can match adult animals with their babies.

Challenge children to name more animals and their babies. Have them see if they can compare the relationship between the adult animal and its baby with the relationship adult humans have with their babies.

Help multilingual learners understand that baby animals have special names. Some names, such as calf, can be used for several adult animals (cow, elephant, deer). Point out that the name for a baby goat is a kid! A kid is also a name people use for children.

Add sensory engagement and support by providing auditory representations of each animal. Demonstrate or provide recordings of cat sounds vs. kitten sounds. As you make the sounds or play recordings, ask children if they can tell which sound is the mama sound and which sound is the baby.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials “The Chicks Say, ‘Pio, Pio, Pio,’” Vocabulary Cards

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we read our Big Chart together. Can you remember what noise the chicks made?

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Teach Revisit these Vocabulary cards: chicks, keep an eye on, adult, communicate, and shelter.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: In “The Chicks Say, ‘Pio, Pio, Pio’,” we can find a lot of the vocabulary words we learned about this week. Today our activity is about matching this week’s vocabulary words to the pictures in the Big Chart.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Set Up Display “The Chicks Say, ‘Pio, Pio, Pio.’” Lay out these Vocabulary Cards: chicks, keep an eye on, adult, communicate, and shelter.

Ask Read and talk about the first picture on the Big Chart. In this picture, I see a mama hen with her baby chicks. So I know that the word chicks fits with this picture. Which other words can fit in the first picture?

Repeat Continue this activity with the rest of the pictures until all of the five vocabulary words have been used. Provide additional support and prompting as needed and take time to review specific vocabulary words as necessary.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Why does the word chicks go with all four pictures?

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Limit the selection from five Vocabulary Cards to two Vocabulary Cards at a time. Then, have the children select which Vocabulary Card matches. Both cards might match which will help to further the conversation.
Ask children to think about why the Vocabulary Card words travel, journey, and waddles might not work with any of the pictures in “The Chicks Say, ‘Pio, Pio, Pio.’”

Take time, as needed, to revisit and review all eight of the Vocabulary Cards for the week. Say the word aloud and have children repeat the word after you. Revisit some of the accompanying pantomimes that children learned in large group this week.

Have children stand up and act out the Big Chart story “The Chicks Say, ‘Pio, Pio, Pio’” and the five Vocabulary Cards: chicks, adult, communicate, shelter, and keep an eye on. Connecting muscle movement with new concepts will foster better understanding of new terms learned.
